Why has the need to build an integrated European venture capital market not moved on since 1984?  Research and innovation was formerly in SIP.  Why is it not now in COSME?
#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-03-14 00:00:00	Prelude	50	As part of the programme for Government and the action plan for jobs
column2: the Government is looking at the introduction of a loan guarantee facility and also a microfinance fund.  We hope to have those up and running fairly shortly.  I might pass the question on the venture capital to Mr. Cooney in a moment.  I did not catch the third question.

column1: #NickyMcFadden	unknown-#NickyMcFadden-party	unknown-#NickyMcFadden-dob	unknown-#NickyMcFadden-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-03-14 00:00:00	Prelude	51	Why is research and innovation not funded under COSME?

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-03-14 00:00:00	Prelude	52	There seemed to be confusion in the mind of the public between the old framework research programme and the competitiveness and innovation programme.  The Commission acknowledged that they caused confusion.  The COSME box is a development for funding in the order of €150
column2: 000.  From there onwards
column3: we are dealing with more high level research and development performers as SMEs that are more technologically advanced.  It is trying to make clear that the research and development stuff is in one area.  It was confusing to SMEs on the ground.  It has been taken out in order to create more clarity for people on the ground.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-03-14 00:00:00	Prelude	53	In the round
column2: the European venture capital system may not have improved dramatically since 1984.  The statistic provided is a European average.  However
column3: there has been a significant change in Ireland and we are recognised as one of the most improved nations in terms of venture capital over the last couple of decades.  At the moment
column4: there is €630 million in seed and venture capital funds under management in Ireland
column5: which is a dramatic change in the last two decades.  We welcome any efforts that are being made to develop further the European venture capital system.  We are competing internationally against the US and so on for the types of companies that can provide the growth and jobs that are needed
column6: especially at this time of economic recovery.  We welcome the measures here which allow us to compete.

Their trade over the last few years was to lend for property and only a small cohort - usually the older staff - know how to lend to small businesses.My experience has been that venture capital is not an option for small businesses employing fewer than 50 people.  A business with more than 50 employees will experience much more success in accessing venture capital
column2: because it will be considered a bit more permanent and will typically have a longer history.  The small microbusinesses have been free of venture capital and therefore
column3: have been more reliant on the banks.  Advice was given to people to go to the CRO
column4: but only 150 businesses have gone to that office since it was formed.  There is a jaded mentality in businesses at the moment.  They have been around the block so long on these issues that going to the CRO will not make any difference for them.  Is the CRO any different in culture than the banks?The EU progress microfinance facility was mentioned
column5: and this was identified in March 2010.  It has been drawn down by 11 countries.  Ireland is not one of them and in that period of time
column6: about 4
column7: 000 businesses have gone bust.  If the ISME figures are correct
column8: half of these failures were due to credit reasons.  We know that funding is of emergency concern for most of these businesses.How much is available to Ireland in the existing scheme and in the upcoming scheme?  Is it the case that it is available and the State has drawn down a certain amount so far?  In other words
column9: is there a disparity between what is available and what is being drawn down?  How much is Government funding through the EU?  How much is leveraged private funding?  How would a business in Navan
column10: County Meath
column11: with ten employees
column12: access this funding tomorrow?  What steps does it need to take?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-03-14 00:00:00	Prelude	63	In regard to what the Minister for Jobs
column2: Enterprise and Innovation is doing to try to ensure that bank credit and finance generally are available to small businesses
column3: there are two measures under the programme for Government.  One is the temporary partial credit guarantee scheme
column4: which will provide a level of guarantee to banks to encourage them to lend to two particular types of companies where there is market failure
column5: that is essentially
column6: companies which do not have collateral or companies which have a novel product or are lending into new markets of which the banks do not have a great knowledge.  To give them greater comfort about their lending and to ensure they can educate themselves in this regard in order that lending can eventually return to normalised patterns and these types of novel companies will be able to access normal bank lending
column7: there is this temporary partial credit guarantee scheme.  The second measure
column8: which the Deputy mentioned
column9: is the micro-finance scheme.  The programme for Government contains a proposal that a micro-finance lending scheme be established.  It would lend amounts of up to approximately €25
column10: 000 to businesses that would have between one and ten employees.  The structures for that are being finalised at present.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-03-14 00:00:00	Prelude	67	Our target would be quarter two.I would like to mention the EU progress facility.  I should explain that it does not come under the COSME proposal with which we are dealing today.  The EU progress facility guarantees a level of lending by micro-credit facilities.  It provides guarantees to eligible intermediaries who have applied to be intermediaries under this EIF scheme.  It will partially cover the portfolio of micro-loans.  In this way
column2: micro-finance is inherently unsustainable in that it tends not to make money
column3: as such.  It is very important for job creation but it is not financially profitable.  To sustain micro-finance lending
column4: the EIF institution guarantees a level of the loan portfolio.  The intermediaries are basically micro-finance lenders.  They are quite often a mix of public-private institutions.  The accreditation process to the EIF facility is managed by the micro-credit lender.  They do not lend funds to countries
column5: they lend or guarantee lending to individual micro-finance lenders and that enables them to sustain the fund for longer in order to lend more to micro-enterprise.  When one talks about drawdown
column6: it is a lending guarantee that would be called on when the micro-credit facility incurs bad debts.

I spoke to a person dealing with the fund in Europe a number of weeks ago and was told that no organisations in Ireland have availed of this facility
column2: and that was the position up to three weeks ago
column3: while 11 other countries had.  We are all very conscious of the real emergencies experienced by businesses.  Today a number of companies will go out of business
column4: and in the case of some of those it will be due to a lack of credit.  I always want to impart that sense of urgency in respect of this issue.  Given the fact that this fund was available since last March and that it might be next September before it is functioning
column5: it is difficult for us to note that timescale and compare it with the level of demand there is for it at present.
